about when you are helping other people
learn how to use Unreal Engine. Um, one
is using control key and mouse wheel
when you're in like blueprints and
everything. That lets you zoom further
than you would normally be able to.
Also, double clicking control will show
exactly where your mouse is at any given
moment. And the widget reflector. This
is a nice one for just very easily
making everything on your screen bigger.
If you're teaching in a way where people
have to look at a screen from far away
or you just know anyone might not have
perfect eyesight, uh that's a good way
to just make everything bigger on the
screen. Also, something we use a lot for
teaching is changing the thickness of
boxes. This isn't actually just for
trigger boxes. This works with anything
like post-process volumes and whatnot
that often have very thin lines. It
helps with visibility. It makes it
easier to click on. And speaking of
making things easier to click on, uh,
don't forget that pressing the T key on

and stuff like that. Uh, these are going

roughness at any value lower than one

Also, speaking of things that change if

Um pawn this is a a cool tip from June
on my team. The pawn um can replicate in
two different ways. The controller can
only replicate in one way. Um and we got
a little uh QR code here. We'll have,
you know, periodic QR codes if you're
like hyper interested in looking more
into one particular thing. But when it
comes to replication, the pawn can use
both the on-server event and the
multiccast event, but the player
controller can only use the onserver
event. And replicated actors can only
use the multiccast event. Keep that in
mind if you're doing a multiplayer game.
Um, rep notify is one that I recently
started using. And this might not be
best practices. This is just something I
got very excited about for my particular
workflow. Um, rep notify, if you don't
know, it looks for when a variable
changes and it creates a function
automatically and it will allow a thing
to happen when a variable changes. And
I've been doing this in single player
experiences, which is weird because it
is a replicated sort of thing. And there
are more efficient ways to do that. You
can, of course, um, you know, have set
functions and things like that that are
also looking for when things change.
Obviously, don't do things on event tick
if you don't have to. Um, but I just
like the fact that this is a very clean
way to have a thing happen when a
variable changes for rendering. Uh,
Stephen Phillips back in Orlando uh,

movie render Q render out H.264 MP4

could, you know, render out these giant

like a quick preview of one of your
sequences, it was a little bit
difficult. And you could, you know,
enable the Apple ProRes plugin and do
anov file, but that could also get

simple way now, if you just want to do a

whatever kind of compression and quality

coming to. Um, similarly, this is uh

Again, seems a bit like a no duh thing,

uh my solution file and then just kind

So these when you have a plugin or

These are things are being specified. So

And then I just mention here sometimes
I've also gone as far as deleting the

and so just by removing that entirely
it's going to compile for more things or
it will try to. So, that's been useful
for us. Um, when your sequencer ends, I

I'm teaching students, who are like,
"Hey, it got to the end of the sequencer

things were." That's the default
behavior. Um, on a case-by case basis,
you can rightclick on your sequencer
track. You can go to properties. You can
change it to keep state, which would
mean when it gets to the end, it um
stays whatever it is doing. It stays
whatever it is doing. Yeah, that's
English. at the end of uh wherever the
sequencer ends. Um restore state of
course is what will bring it back to the
beginning. But if you want to change
that default behavior, you can actually
go into default engine and change it

default engine is something that you can

So, this is a very specific little tip.
I'm going to do like these are pretty

like here's a little bit more of a deep

Blender and Maya. So you simulate

Blender. Um you export it all as an
Olympic cache file. So an ABC file. Um
important for all simulated meshes.
Apply the scale and set all origins to
center of mass. So settings setting
settings. And then um you go into Maya

with like thousands of particles, but
for whatever reason, that is what has

I found, that was Dante's workflow. This

of works and looks good and runs very

um my friend here in the uh speakers

And it's a very clean way to connect a

the only tricky thing here is we're not

It automatically creates um the or uses

Similar when you're doing uh live link
live body retargeting that just becomes
a live link animation class. So, you
don't touch that at all. But if you want
to start mixing and matching motion data
from different sources, um this is our
favorite node in the animation graph.
It's called layered blend per bone. And
what it allows you to do is take
different sources. Some of it can be,
you know, pre-rendered animation like an
idle pose that you might want to revert
back to if you're missing data. Um it
can be coming from LiveLink face. It can
be coming from MetaQuest Pro. So what we
do is we take whatever body data we can
get from Makopi, move and trace,
whatever. Um, and then we combine that
with face data from something like
MetaQuest Pro, hopefully Apple Vision
Pro soon as well, as well as the hand
data and then you can end up with a very
uh clever full body solution. And very
quickly, so the idea with layered blend
per bone is you basically filter out uh
the data that's coming in at different
points. So in the top example, this is
for making sure that everything with the
face is coming from like here up. And
then down here, this is making sure that
the hand data is coming in as well
because the face and the body of course
are different um animation graphs for
the metahuman setup. And then you'll see
very briefly here, this was a test we

with uh movement. This was with Makopi
and with uh the meta movement SDK and we

compare some different ways to combine
this data using that um layered blend
per bone node and I'll just kind of skim

coming in at the same time. You can see
that we baked it out in sequencer here

best combination of different data. So
we've got merged here. Some of it coming

started to play with the lovely mega

Vive trackers. And it was just a good

data registers in different ways. We
ended up with some interesting rotation
offsets that can be corrected. But um
yeah, the the big takeaway here is play
with that layered blend per bone node if
you want to use different animation data
from different sources.
Cool. Uh quick modeling tip, the mesh

that that joyful moment using 3D

Um, we're finding that because of how

Reducing meshes in editor. I'm
embarrassed. Most members of my team
knew this way before me. I didn't know
that you could actually reduce the uh
the triangles directly inside Unreal
Engine without having to like reimpport
things. It's just right over there. When
you open up your mesh properties, uh,
under reduction settings, percent
triangles, if something starts at 4,000

want it to be 40% of that, and then it
comes down to about 1,600. Pretty
straightforward, pretty cool. And you
can do that on a per lod level. Um, and
then, of course, this will be reflected
when you're packaged, but it's
non-destructive. So, if you're doing
this just in editor, you can always go
back from 40 back up to 100 if you want

This was an interesting one. Like I just
went down this weird rabbit hole one day
where I was like, "What's the difference
between these and like when should you
use one?" And I I pretty much have all
the information here, but um I think you
might be surprised to know which of
these is the most expensive. And I'll
just tell you, it goes from the top
down. So text is the most expensive
primarily because it is localized. So if
you're releasing something that's going
to be in a lot of different languages,
text is great for that, but it needs to
kind of think the hardest about it. So
that actually has the highest cost.
String is case sensitive. It's mutable
text. Um it may need to be formatted.
And name, name is actually the cheapest,
believe it or not. It's not case
sensitive. There's no localization. Um
it's really useful for little
identifiers, keys, variables where you
need frequent comparisons, and you're
just checking does this key equal this
key. So keep that in mind. Um this is I
think something everyone who is in game

year. Relatively recent for me. So, I

just make the collision a little bit
bigger? Like, it's one of another one of
those kind of duh moments that I'm sure

a nice discovery for me to be like,
yeah, of course, just grow grow that

you're doing a simple collision like a

uh Do I have a laser pointer? I do. the

But now with the admittedly expensive

And uh classic question going back to
decades of Unreal Engine use. Uh what do
you do when you see lighting needs to be
rebuilt? I just wanted to bring this up.
It's been covered in other talks even
here at Unrealest. But there's a few
different approaches. One of course is
disable all screen messages. And by the
way, here's the funny thing is like it
tells you this right here. But if you're
like me, I don't read text that isn't
read and loud. So like I never actually
like looked at this for years. And so
yes, you can disable all screen
messages. That'll make it make it go
away. But for, you know, the first eight
years of me learning Unreal, I never
actually tried typing in that console
command. And it's a good one because it
actually tells you these are the things
that need to be rebuilt cuz sometimes
I'd be like, I have no idea what these
24 objects are. What is the problem? And
sometimes it's like there's just a weird
glitch. There's something going on where
like for whatever reason those objects
aren't building and rather than trying
to troubleshoot it, like just go and
make them movable or delete them if you
don't need them or refresh them. Um, but
it is really handy to be like these are
the particular objects that are throwing
that error. And also, if you're in full
lumen mode, nanite mode, or you're not
casting shadows, you're not going to
bake your lighting, don't forget that
you can go into your project settings
and just disable allow static lighting
entirely.
Light mixer. Um, this is one of those
things that has been in a lot of other
applications. I think when I first
started using 3ds Max in like 2004, it
had this. And so, for the longest time,
I was like, we need this in Unreal. So,
I was so happy a couple versions ago
when we finally got this. It's a
one-stop shop to see all the lighting in
your scene. And you can pull out all
sorts of different columns with
different data. You can edit it in
groups. You can create collections. Um,
you can set things to be movable if
you're doing like a quick test where
you're like, what would this look like
if instead of baked everything was like
full-on lumen and you know, compare your
frame rates and then change it back. I
do want to note though that for whatever
reason, uh, skylight does not show up in
here. So, if you've got a skylight in

affecting the lighting and you've maybe
that's set to be baked and it shows up
as like an unbaked object or something
like that, you do want to make sure that
you're looking at that. In addition to
everything here, you also have the
environment light mixer. The skylight
does show up there. All the mixers are
are good places to kind of keep track of
the atmospheric and lighting and fog and
clouds and all that fun stuff going on
in your scene. Um, lights are very cheap
if you don't cast shadows. Again, seems
obvious, but uh I think I found myself
often times, especially when I first
started to build virtual reality in

It's you can't have too many lights that

it free. You know, longer Unreal Engine
no longer needs to think about it. Of
course, stationary lights, even baked,
are a little more expensive than static
lights. But basically, like if you don't
think the shadow is doing a lot for your
particular moment in the scene, turn it
off. And you see that the difference
between not casting the light at all and
just not casting shadow is pretty
